name: More Stories of the American Dream Quiz | Entertainment | 10 Questions

questions.text: In "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf", the principal characters are given "classic" American names. What are the names?
questions.explanation:
George and Martha.

	Edward Albee's tale of curious people and even more curious relationships. Much of the tension in the plot derives from George's failure to rise in his career.

questions.text: Who earned outstanding reviews for his direction of the movie version of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf"?
questions.explanation:
Mike Nichols.

	Burton, Liz Taylor, George Segal and Sandy Dennis. Long, but interesting.

questions.text: "A Place in the Sun" is a solid movie about ambition and frustration. What plot does Monty Clift hatch to dispose of Shelley Winters?
questions.explanation:
Drowning.

	From the Theodore Dreiser novel,"An American Tragedy". Fine job by Monty, Winters and Liz Taylor. It's hard to climb the ladder when you have "baggage".

questions.text: The definitive tale of the American Dream is probably "Death of A Salesman". What is the name of the salesman?
questions.explanation:
Willy Loman.

	A landmark character in American theatre, Willy doesn't quite achieve the American Dream. Weber is from "You Can't Go Home Again" (Thomas Wolfe). Flood is from "The Dark At The Top of the Stairs" (William Inge). Carraway is from "The Great Gatsby" (F. Scott Fitzgerald).

questions.text: Napoleon Hill is an American success story; he also shares his secrets of success with the public in his many books. Which of the following is one of his writings?
options: Be All That You Can Be
How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying
How To Win Friends and Influence People
questions.explanation:
Think and Grow Rich.

	"Think" is probably his best known book. Hill grew up in poverty - but found the secret(s) of success. "win Friends" is by Dale Carnegie. "Trying" was a play. "Be" is the slogan for the U.S. Army.

questions.text: "Main Street" lampoons American society. Who is the author?
questions.explanation:
Sinclair Lewis.

	Lewis was critical of American society and values in novels such as "Main Street", Babitt", etc.

questions.text: In regard to the American Dream, it must be observed that "the best laid plans of mice and men" often go awry. Who wrote the novel "Of Mice and Men"?
questions.explanation:
John Steinbeck.

	The sad tale of George and Lenny.

questions.text: The American Dream is often represented by the life and legend of Abraham Lincoln: the rise from a log cabin and rail-splitting to the presidency. Who starred in the movie version of "Abe Lincoln in Illinois"?
questions.explanation:
Raymond Massey.

	Great performance by Massey in the fine movie version of Robert E. Sherwood's play. (Fonda played Lincoln in "Young Mr. Lincoln".)

John Dos Passos.

	Dos Passos takes a long look at America. Kafka wrote "America". De Tocqueville wrote "Democracy in America".

questions.text: It is common to speak of a "rags-to-riches" rise as a "Horatio Alger story". Who was Horatio Alger?
questions.explanation:
Author.

	Alger's many novels (from the mid-late nineteenth century) often tell of young American boys and men who triumph over hardship and misfortune.
